newsitem.title: FINLAND: GERMAN 1997 DEFICIT TOO HIGH FOR EMU - THINK TANK.
newsitem.headline: GERMAN 1997 DEFICIT TOO HIGH FOR EMU - THINK TANK.

text.p: A Finnish economic think tank forecast in a report on Wednesday that Germany's public sector deficit to gross domestic product would be bigger in 1997 than the three percent allowed to qualify for the third stage of EMU.
"It looks like Germany's budget deficit will exceed the criterion ... despite additional savings and the assumed pick-up in growth," the Research Institute of the Finnish Economy (ETLA) said.
"The German budget deficit is, however, likely to be below four percent of total output," ETLA said.

The problem in Germany and elsewhere in Europe was that the additional public sector expenditure cuts required to put public finances in shape for EMU were widely unpopular and so potentially very costly for politicians, the think tank said.

In 1997 -- the year of reckoning -- only five of the European Union's member countries would live up to the public sector deficit to GDP criterion of at most three percent, it said, listing Luxembourg, Denmark, Ireland, the Netherlands and Finland.
In France, another key country for the start of the third phase of Economic and Monetary Union, the 1997 public sector deficit would also be too high, about 3.5 percent of GDP, ETLA said.

The single currency entry criteria agreed at Maastricht in 1991 would have to be interpreted flexibly, ETLA said, adding it expected the third phase to start on schedule in January 1999 with Germany, France, the Benelux countries and Austria.
If they so choose, Denmark, Ireland and Finland could be in the first wave.
"Because the EU-countries' governments have committed themselves politically to EMU it looks likely that it will be implemented from the start of 1999," it said.
Looking at gross public debt to GDP, ETLA said only Luxembourg, France and Britain would remain below the 60 percent maximum allowed. Germany and Finland would be close.
"The gross public debt criterion is probably going to be interpreted so that Belgium can be admitted," ETLA said.
It put Belgium's gross public debt to GDP at over 130 percent in 1997.
